Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: New Challenges in Geometric Search and Retrieval

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Geometric retrieval is the problem of preprocessing multi-dimensional
geometric data for rapid access. Efficient geometric search and
retrieval are of fundamental importance in engineering and science, and
have numerous applications in areas as diverse as knowledge discovery
and data mining, pattern recognition and classification, machine
learning, data compression, multimedia databases, document retrieval,
and statistics. Given the high complexity of exact solutions to these
problems, researchers have been led to consider these problems in the context
of approximation, where small errors in distance are tolerated.

Over recent years, there have been many advances in our understanding of
the computational complexity of approximation algorithms for proximity
searching. This has ranged from the development of a theory of the best
space-time tradeoffs achievable for these problems to practical software
systems. Nonetheless, there are still many important, challenging
problems that remain. Research under this award will both deepen and broaden
our understanding of the computational complexity of approximate
proximity searching. In particular, PI will study new data
structures for polytope membership queries, polytope-based approaches to
approximate nearest neighbor searching, simplification and unification
of proximity data structures, dynamic data structures for proximity
searching, and software implementations of these algorithms and data
structures.

In addition to the contributions of new algorithms and data structures,
software systems and libraries will be developed as part of this
research, which will be made freely available over the Web to help
scientists and engineers in other disciplines solve their own
application problems that involve nearest neighbor and range searching.
The geometric retrieval algorithms, developed as a part of this
research, will be incorporated into a graduate-level course in
computational geometry. Course materials will be made available over the
Web as a resource for researchers interested in learning about this
area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has focused on the development of new efficient algorithms for several computational problems in the area of geometric retrieval. Geometric retrieval involves preprocessing multi-dimensional geometric data for rapid access. This area is of fundamental importance in many areas of engineering and science, and it has applications in diverse areas such as knowledge discovery and data mining, pattern recognition and classification, machine learning, data compression, multimedia databases, document retrieval, and computational statistics.

The work of this project has led to both faster algorithms and a deeper understandings of the computational complexity of several problems in geometric retrieval. These include approximate nearest-neighbor searching and range searching, approximating convex polytopes, dynamic data structures for maintaining spatial data sets, statistical estimation that is robust to errors, and computing approximate minimum-cost spanning trees in multi-dimensional spaces. This project has also contributed to the development of advanced computational tools and methodologies, such as space-time tradeoffs for approximate Voronoi diagrams (AVDs), geometric branch-and-bound, and geometric sampling through the application of two classical concepts from geometry, the Mahler volume and Macbeath regions.

These improved algorithms will lead to more efficient solutions to the applications described above. Software systems and libraries developed as part of this project have been made freely available over the Web to help scientists and engineers in other disciplines. The algorithms developed as a part of this project have been incorporated into graduate and undergraduate courses at the University of Maryland, and course materials are available over the Web as a resource for students and researchers. This project has also supported several students who have been involved in the project’s research program, both in the form of undergraduate research projects and graduate student dissertations.
